pain during his execution, thus violating his rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also filed a similar complaint in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City alleging that the defendants failed to follow Maryland law because the execution protocol had not been adopted under the Maryland Administrative Procedures Act (MAPA).[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2006 the Maryland Court of Appeals invalidated the Maryland execution protocols until such time as they were properly adopted under MAPA or exempted from that requirement by an act of the Maryland General Assembly.[SENTMARKER]On January 29, 2007, two bills were introduced in the Maryland General Assembly, one that would exempt the death penalty protocols from the MAPA requirement and one that would repeal the death penalty in the state.[SENTMARKER]The judge agreed to stay the proceedings of this case pending the outcome of the legislation.[SENTMARKER]According to the status report on March 14, 2011, all executions in Maryland had been stayed until the proper administrative regulations were adopted.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012 this case was administratively closed.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013 the Maryland legislature repealed the death penalty for all future convictions and in December 2014 Governor O'Malley commuted the death sentences of the four remaining death-row inmates to life without the possibility of parole.

gold_sents: In response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, Congress passed the CARES Act, which created, among other things, the “Paycheck Protection Program.”[SENTMARKER]Under this program, small business owners could apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration; if they later certified that all of the loan funds had been used for qualifying expenses, the loan would be forgiven.[SENTMARKER]The SBA’s rules disqualified many small business owners with criminal records.[SENTMARKER]Several small business owners brought this lawsuit against the SBA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, challenging this criminal record exclusion.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, the court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the SBA to extend the application deadline for the named plaintiffs from June 30 to July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The following week, Congress passed follow-up legislation extending the deadline for all applicants to August 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of July 29, 2020, further developments in the litigation are pending.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.

pegasus_output_sents: In May 1997, a group of disabled concert-goers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act (CADA) in connection with the operation of Fiddler's Green Amphitheater.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, when purchasing tickets for concerts at the amphitheater, persons with mobility limitations who use wheelchairs or other mobility aids have only one choice of wheelchair seating at a single specified price.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants, Fey Concert Company, Universal Concerts, Inc., Every Dog Has Its Day, Inc, and the Museum of Outdoor Arts (MOA) continued to advertise and/or claim that they sell tickets for "wheelchair seating" in the reserved seating section.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants negligently misrepresented the wheelchair seating area as being that area described in paragraph 33 of the ADA, and that they engaged in common law negligent misrepresentation, fraud and fraudulent concealment as to the individual named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and ordered the defendants to pay a total of $9,900 in damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida entered a judgment against the State of Florida for violating Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to serve qualified individuals with disabilities in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires public entities to provide services, programs, and activities that are appropriate to the needs of qualified people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the State failed to meet this requirement by failing, among other things, to provide in-home services to children and young adults who entered nursing facilities as children and grew up in these institutions, unnecessarily segregated from their communities, and limited access to the type of interactions that promote physical, psychological, and social development.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the defendants violated the ADA by not providing these individuals with sufficient access to community-based services and deficient assessment and transition planning processes.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay a total of $1 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2013, the Philadelphia Public Library was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania by a group of blind library patrons who alleged that the library's e-book lending program violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (R.A.).[SENTMARKER]The ADA prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability and requires institutions in receipt of federal funds to make their programs and activities accessible to all people, including those who are deaf, blind, or have other print disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires that all electronic resources comply with federal accessibility guidelines.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' complaint alleged that by lending out e-books, the library discriminated against its blind patrons and needlessly excluded them from its programs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement in which the Library agreed to comply with the ADA and to make its e-reader lending program accessible to both blind and non-blind patrons.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought by Thomas and Dianna Bradley in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas on behalf of their autistic son.[SENTMARKER]The Bradleys alleged that the Arkansas Department of Education, the Williford School District, and several school district officials violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was then consolidated and the Bradleys filed a second suit in 2000 naming the same defendants as the first.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the district court held a bench trial on the case and issued written findings of fact and conclusions of law.[SENTMARKER]The court determined that none of the defendants violated federal law.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2000, Thomas and Dianna Bradley filed this lawsuit against the Arkansas Department of Education, the Williford School District, and several school district officials in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide a free appropriate education in the least restrictive environment for their son, David Bradley.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for dismissal or in the alternative for summary judgment on a number of grounds, including that the statute lacked an unequivocal expression of Congress's intent to abrogate the states' Eleventh Amendment immunity.[SENTMARKER]On August 30, 2002, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals issued an opinion, finding that Ray Simon, Marcia Harding and Mike Crowley were entitled to immunity and dismissed all claims for money damages against these individuals.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2000, a student in the Visalia Unified School District (VUSD) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the VUSD, alleging discrimination based on sexual orientation in violation of the federal civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the district had a policy designed to deter gay or lesbian students from being open about their sexual orientation and to prevent them from freely associating with one another.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, students who are gay 15 or who are perceived to be gay are verbally harassed by their classmates, who refer to them in 16 the classrooms and the hallways as "faggots, " "fags," "queers," and "homos."[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that one gay student at Golden West High School was attacked on campus by other students and that the school district did not fund, sponsor, endorse, or promote any organization within the district to provide support to students who were the victims of anti-gay harassment.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the district agreed to create a mandatory training program for all students in one grade level in all VUSD high schools and 20 continuation schools on the subject of preventing harassment and discrimination on the basis of actual or perceived sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The training program will be conducted in courses in which the district already addresses other forms of discrimination, or otherwise addresses school safety issues.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed to develop a school site plan for preventing discrimination.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2000, a student at Golden West High School in Visalia, California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Visalia Unified School District (VUSD) alleging discrimination on the basis of his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that he was harassed and discriminated against by students, teachers, and administrators because of his actual or perceived sexual orientation, and that the VUSD failed to provide him with an independent study program to allow him to complete his high school graduation requirements.[SENTMARKER]The district denied the complaint and filed a motion to dismiss, which was denied by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion to strike and summarily adjudicate the case.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the NAACP and its state and local units filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) alleging that the OCR's March 2018 Manual violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) by requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the parties announced that settlement negotiations had broken down and OCR planned to release a revised OCR Case Processing Manual later that day, which could render Plaintiffs' requests for relief moot.[SENTMARKER]The next day, Plaintiffs sought leave to file an amended complaint and a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction to add allegations that Defendants were also using section 108(k) of the March 2018 manual to dismiss complaints on the basis that a similar complaint filed by another individual had been previously dismissed pursuant to section108(t) and that a citywide moratorium on police chokeholds did not moot an otherwise valid claim for injunctive relief because the moratorium was not permanent.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs ultimately notified the Court that they did not intend to file a motion for a preliminary injunction after all.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to provide the Court with an update on the status of the directed investigations pursuant to paragraph 2 of the amended complaint.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education (DOE) and the Office for Civil Rights (OCR) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by changing the way complaints of discrimination are handled by OCR.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the defendants changed the way OCR handled complaints that were part of "a pattern" of complaints by an individual complainant against multiple recipients.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that this change violated the ADA and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and violated the right of complainants to appeal OCR's determinations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to dismiss all of the complaints by the end of the case.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, the day after Proposal 2 passed, a group of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights, and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the provisions of Proposal 2 affecting public colleges and universities violated the United States Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Attorney General's Motion for Summary Judgment and dismissed the Complaint on its merits.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the District Court upheld Proposal 2, concluding that the charter amendment was enacted in circumstances where widespread racial discrimination in the sale and rental of housing led to segregated housing, forcing many to live in "unhealthful, unsanitary and overcrowded conditions"

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Rule 23(a)(3) requires the Court to determine whether the representative parties' claims are typical of the claims of the class.[SENTMARKER]Typicality is satisfied where the named plaintiffs' claims rest on the same legal theory and arise "from the same event or practice" that gives rise to the other class members' claims.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 14, 2013, Catholic Charities of Kalamazoo (together, "MCC plaintiffs") filed suit in the District Court for the Western District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the contraceptive-coverage requirement violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Free Exercise, Free Speech, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2013, the plaintiffs moved for preliminary injunctions in their respective district courts.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a preliminary injunction on all claims because the plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted this petition, vacated our judgment, and remanded the case back to us for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's decision in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc., 134 S.Ct.[SENTMARKER]2751 (July 19, 2014), the Affordable Care Act's "contraceptive mandate."

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2009, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint in federal court in Mobile, Alabama, alleging that First United Security Bank, now known as First US Bank, charged African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly-situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the bank unlawfully failed to provide its lending products and serv ices on an equal basis to majority African-Americans in west central Alabama, a practice known as redlining.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2014, the parties filed a joint notice to report on the status of implementation of the settlement terms, as set forth in the Agreed Order for Resolution ("Amended Agreement"), entered by the Court on May 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties continue to work cooperatively to ensure the smooth and full implementation of various aspects of the agreement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On October 23, 2006, the FDIC conducted a compliance examination of First United Security Bank of Tuscaloosa, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC determined that in 2004 the Bank engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants, on the basis of race, in the pricing of conventional, first-lien refinance loans on owner-occupied, one-to-four family properties, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the Fair Housing Act, and their implementing regulations.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009, this court entered an Agreed Order for Resolution between the FDIC, the Attorney General, and the Bank.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the Bank to comply with the terms of the Order.[SENTMARKER]The Bank also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $325,000.

gold_sents: In 2014, a non-profit organization that provides housing assistance to formerly incarcerated individuals filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, who owned and managed a multi-building apartment complex, had a discriminatory policy that unlawfully prohibited anyone with a criminal record from renting an apartment.[SENTMARKER]After years of discovery and litigation, the parties settled for over $1 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 3, 2019, The Fortune Society filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against Sandcastle Towers Housing Development Fund Corporation, Sarasota Gold LLC, E M Associates LLC, and Weissman Realty Group LLC for violating the Fair Housing Act of 1968.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of illegal discrimination on the basis of race and color at The Sand Castle, a multi-building apartment complex they own and manage in Queens, New York.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the defendants' policy of automatically excluding any person with a record of a criminal conviction from renting or living in an apartment was consistent with a policy of limiting the number of new minority tenants in the building.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of standing was denied.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Fortune Society, a not-for-profit organization that provides reentry and reintegration services to formerly incarcerated individuals in New York City, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York in October 2014 against The Sand Castle Towers Housing Development Fund Corp. and its owner, Sandcastle Towers, alleging that the defendants' policy of categorically excluding applicants with felony or non-traffic misdemeanor convictions from tenancy caused an unjustified disparate impact on African-American and Hispanic applicants in violation of the Fair Housing Act. After discovery, both parties moved for summary judgment on this disparate-impact claim.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. Lindsay thereafter awarded plaintiffs $5,255,108.94 in attorneys fees and costs from Garden City.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 2019, Judge Spatt signed the parties’ stipulation of discontinuance with prejudice, except without prejudice as to the court’s jurisdiction for the purpose of interpretation or enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the County to pay $5,400,000 to the plaintiffs to be used for the purpose of furthering and promoting mixed-income affordable housing; $120,000 to NYCC to be used for activities related to fair and affordable housing; and $400,000 to plaintiffs’ counsel for attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, MHANY Management, Inc., a non-profit community-based developer of affordable housing incorporated in New York, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Village of Garden City, the Garden City Board of Trustees, and the County of Nassau.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by re-zoneing approximately twenty-five acres of County-owned land to prevent affordable housing from being built, which would likely be occupied by minorities.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2012, the Court granted summary judgment to the County, and dismissed the case against the County.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2010, the district court granted NYCC permission to intervene in the Action as practical successor to ACORN.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed, in part, the final judgment, and remanded the case for further proceedings.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, a group of individuals and organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the County of Nassau, the Village of Garden City, and the Garden City Board of Trustees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Civil Rights Act of 1866 and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by re-zoneing two parcels of Nassau County-owned land to prevent the building of low-and-middle-income housing on that site.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied any wrongdoing, and assert that they have no racially discriminatory policies.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 17, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Texas filed this lawsuit against Nixon State Bank, a Texas-based bank.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon charged higher prices for unsecured consumer loans on the basis of national origin, including charging higher rates of interest, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its loan officers effectively to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement, Nixon agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures to ensure that prices it charges for the loans covered by this Order, including the portion of the price that reflects the discretion of the loan officer or any company employee, are set in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The bank also agreed to compensate its Hispanic borrowers of unsecured loans.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The United States of America filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Nixon State Bank.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon engaged in a pattern or practice of lending discrimination on the basis of national origin in the pricing of unsecured consumer loans in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Nixon agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure that the prices it charges for the loans covered by this order were set in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that Nixon would compensate its Hispanic borrowers and provide equal credit opportunity training to its management officials.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Texas filed this civil rights case in the United States District Court for the District of Dallas.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Houston Area Urban League, the Urban League of Greater Dallas, and the Business and Community Leaders of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement policies and procedures designed to ensure that the price charged for its residential loan products, including the portion of the mortgage that reflects the discretion of the loan officer or any other company employee, is set in a nondiscriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act and the Community Reinvestment Act.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to compensate certain African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2008, the Federal Reserve System conducted an examination of the lending practices of PrimeLending, a wholly-owned subsidiary of PlainsCapital Bank, a bank chartered by the Texas Department of Banking, to evaluate compliance with the Fair Housing Act, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and the Federal Housing Administration.[SENTMARKER]The Federal Reserve found reason to believe that the defendant had displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $367,900.95 to resolve the claims of the U.S. Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to implement a complaint resolution program.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2013,  the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank, alleging that it charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates it charged white borrowers, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court (Judge Robert A. Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas entered a consent order against Fort Davis State Bank in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) by charging Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires the bank to implement a monitoring program to ensure compliance with ECOA and to provide annual training to its employees with respect to their responsibilities and obligations under ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment against the bank on December 5, 2014.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 31, 2008, the U.N.[SENTMARKER]Department of Justice (D.J.)[SENTMARKER]filed this complaint against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that between 2007 and 2008, Southport charged hundreds of African-American and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher fees on both purchase and refinance home mortgage loans than non-Hispanic white borrowers because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Southport's business practice was to allow its mortgage brokers to vary their fees and thus alter the price set based on a borrower's objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]In September 2008, the bank began to wind down its mortgage lending activities and after November of that year made virtually no new home mortgages loans.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a consent order in which Southport was required to collect, maintain, and report data with respect to certain loan terms and borrower information for residential loans, including the race, national origin of each wholesale residential loan borrower, pursuant to HMDA.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this lawsuit against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin, alleging that the bank discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Southport engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination based on race and national origin in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. On October 11, 2013, the court entered an order enjoining Southport from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin, or in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered Southport to pay a total of $687,000 to the victims of the alleged discrimination.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought by the U.S. Department of Justice under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act of 1985 against the State of Missouri, the St. Louis Board of Education, and the Southbury Training School in the District of Connecticut.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the rights of persons with developmental disabilities by failing to implement the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in 1986, and the district court approved the plan in 1988.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the motion, but the case was re-opened and the parties filed a new motion to re-open the case, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought by the United States against the State of Connecticut, the Department of Mental Retardation, and the director of Southbury Training School in 1986, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. 1997 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The complaint sought to address and address the living conditions at Southbury, a Connecticut institution for persons with developmental disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The district court approved a consent decree in 1988, which required the defendants to submit an implementation plan addressing the procedures by which the consent decree would be effectuated.[SENTMARKER]On October 30, 1996, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case on the grounds that the district court had abused its discretion in finding the defendants in civil contempt of the court's orders.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion, finding that the defendants had not complied with the terms of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal, which was denied on December 12, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Disability Rights Washington filed this class action on behalf of individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in April 2014.[SENTMARKER]They sued the State healthcare authority and department of social services, alleging that budget cuts resulted in inadequate services in violation of the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement one year later and the final settlement was approved in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is ongoing and under court supervision through September 30, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington by a resident of a nursing facility and his next friend and mother.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to adequately screen and evaluate residents of nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to improve their screening and evaluation systems.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to pay the plaintiff's attorneys' fees and litigation costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2014, Disability Rights Washington (DRW) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on behalf of individuals with developmental disabilities who were denied access to services based upon the severity of their disabilities in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement that provided for a 14 comprehensive reform of defendants' Pre-Admission Screening and Resident Referral 15 (PASRR) system, required under the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also established procedures for ensuring timely PASRR I screenings, Level 17 II evaluations, Post-PAsRR Level II meetings, and the provision of specialized 18 services to increase class members' independence and/ or discharge planning for class 19 members who are medically able and willing to live in an alternative placement in the 20 community.[SENTMARKER]The court granted final approval of the settlement on April 16, 2019.

gold_sents: Individuals with intellectual disabilities residing in the Wyoming State Training School filed this lawsuit in 1990 to challenge conditions at the School and a lack of community placement options.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 1991 to a settlement that was designed not only to improve conditions in the institution, but also to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and create options for community living for individuals with intellectual disabilities in Wyoming.[SENTMARKER]The court's jurisdiction was ended in 1994.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 3, 1990, the Wyoming State Training School was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming by individuals with mental retardation and related developmental disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate care and habilitation for the individuals.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Stipulated Agreement in which the parties agreed to address and resolve the following components of the overall issue of care for the identified class: conditions at the state training school, education needs, including pre-school, and the need for community placement.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the defendants agreed to hire two Special Education Consultants to monitor the training school.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 29, 2007, a group of business, labor, and civil rights groups challenged the constitutionality of the Arizona immigration law in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the law was preempted by the federal immigration law provision preempting state regulation "other than through licensing and similar laws."[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the Arizona Attorney General for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, because he lacked the authority to bring enforcement actions.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit entered judgment in favor of the defendants on September 17, 2008, and the case was dismissed on March 9, 2009.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and various business and civil rights organizations (collectively, the Chamber) filed a preenforcement suit in federal court against those charged with administering the Arizona Workers Act, A.R.S.[SENTMARKER]23-211 through 214, enacted July 2, 2007, and effective January 1, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The Chamber argued that the Arizona law’s provisions allowing the suspension and revocation of business licenses for employing unauthorized aliens were both expressly and impliedly preempted by federal immigration law, and that the mandatory use of E-Verify was not.[SENTMARKER]The District Court held that Arizona’s law was not preempted.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the District of Arizona affirmed the District Court's decision in favor of the defendants.

gold_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Supremacy Clause and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution against the state of Arizona and the Governor of Arizona in her official capacity in the U.S. District Court of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, which contains several provisions designed to "discourage and deter the unlawful entry and presence of aliens" in Arizona, impermissibly infringes on the federal government's right to enact and enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the grant of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit, issued an opinion upholding the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted cert on December 12, 2011 and issued their opinion on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part, striking down most of the challenged provisions of S.B.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of organizations and individuals filed a lawsuit against the Sheriff and Attorney of each of the 15 counties in Arizona, in their official capacities, in the U.S. District Court of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by organizations such as the ACLU and the National Immigration Law Center along with private counsel, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was a violation of the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff contends that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 conflicts with federal law and procedures and that local law enforcement agencies are ill equipped to deal with the complexities of immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in February 2012, which the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, Arizona v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| ORG [CONTRACTED] In May 2010, the plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona seeking a declaration that Arizona's Senate Bill 1070 is unconstitutional in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the day labor provisions in S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 violate the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction barring the enforcement of two provisions, which make it unlawful for a motor vehicle occupant to hire or attempt to hire a person for work at another location from a stopped car that impedes traffic, or for a person to be hired in such a manner.[SENTMARKER]In September 2011, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court's decision and held that a Redondo Beach ordinance prohibiting solicitation of business, employment, and contributions on streets and highways 28 was not narrowly tailored to achieve the city's interest in promoting traffic flow and safety and thus violated the free speech guarantees of the First Am endment.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of individuals and organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the state of Arizona and the state's governor, alleging that Arizona's immigration enforcement law, Senate Bill 1070, violated the First Amendment and the Arizona Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2010.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2012, the defendants filed this appeal, which was granted on September 19, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, The Regents of the University of California filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the acting director of ICE's Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).[SENTMARKER]The Regents sought a temporary restraining order enjoining Defendants from implementing the July 6, 2020 memorandum issued by the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), a division of ICE, regarding the status of international students holding F-1 nonimmigrant student visas during the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the SEVP issued an exemption to a preexisting regulation requiring international students on F-1 visas to attend classes in person if they wished to remain in this country.[SENTMARKER]The Regents therefore sought a preliminary injunction order to enjoin Defendants from implementation of the Directive.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the Regents' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on October 10, 2020.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.

gold_sents: This lawsuit arose out of the funding provisions for elementary and secondary schools in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) of 2020.[SENTMARKER]Filed by eight states (California, Michigan, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin), Washington D.C., and four school districts (Chicago, Cleveland, New York City, and San Francisco), the lawsuit challenged a July 1, 2020 interim final rule from the Department of Education about how the funds may be distributed between private and public schools.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the interim final rule.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, the court approved a permanent injunction that prevented the defendants from implementing the April 30 guidance and July 1 rule and from taking any action inconsistent with the proportional share formula in Section 1117 or other restrictions or penalties on the use of CARES Act funds.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction over the case for enforcement purposes.

who lost or risked losing medical coverage due to changes in the AWA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief against the AWA and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 27, gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

A bench trial was held in late 2018, and as of August 12, 2020, the litigation is ongoing as the parties await the court's decision.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2016, a Texas-based Catholic organization, Franciscan Alliance, Inc., filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) alleging sex discrimination under Title IX of the Affordable Care Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS's final rule implementing Section 1557 of the Obamacare Act violated their religious and nondiscrimination rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Equal Protection Act (EPA) by denying them health insurance coverage for services related to gender transition.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for voluntary Remand and Stay on May 2, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2019, the court vacated the injunction and remanded the case to the lower court for further consideration.
