gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On May 30, 2008, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) alleging that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause by implementing a race-based lockdown policy at the High Desert State 21 Prison.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, which the court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties conducted extensive discovery, which included conducting more than two dozen depositions of prison officials, prison leadership, prisoners and experts, and disclosing tens of thousands of pages of documents.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the individual damages claims for certain specified periods, but left intact the class claims for injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 2014, the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) entered into a Stipulated Settlement to settle a class action lawsuit brought by inmates who alleged that race-based lockdowns at California prisons violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the Stipulation to settle all claims for injunctive relief and to implement a policy in section 55015 of the Department Operations Manual 6 consistent with this term of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]In December 2014, the parties filed a motion for class certification, which the Court granted on July 10, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties have submitted a proposed notice to the class concerning the settlement, and the parties' counsel will actively monitor and enforce CDCR’s compliance with the settlement terms during the monitoring period.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.

gold_sents: On May 16, 2020, five individuals filed a class action against Lompoc, a low-security prison facing one of the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 among U.S federal prisons, for immediate relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs proposed a class of all current and future people in post-conviction custody at Lompoc, and sought enlargement of custody to include home confinement, and if the conditions of confinement violated constitutional rights, for prisoners to be released.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO (temporary restraining order), and a preliminary injunction requiring Lompoc to undertake health and safety measures, and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss the case and on October 8, the court granted plaintiff's motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In January 2021, the plaintiffs filed another motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 16, 2020, a prisoner at the United States Penitentiary at Lompoc, California, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Director of the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and the Warden of the facility.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the BOP had failed to respond effectively to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the prison's facilities were unsanitary, overcrowded, and in violation of the Constitution's Eighth Amendment right to a private and family life.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CLASS ||| CIVIL ||| DISPENSING ||| TRO ||| CONCERN [CONCERN] On September 18, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on behalf of inmates at the federal prison in Lompoc, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]Petitioners sought to represent a class consisting of all current and future 8 people in post-conviction custody at the prison (the "Class"), and their joinder was impracticable.[SENTMARKER]The prison must be required to identify the 12 supplies and other materials upon which the institution is dependent, such as food, 13 medical supplies, certain medicines, cleaning products, etc., and prepare for 14 shortages, delays or disruptions in the supply chain.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2020, the BOP issued guidance to all 9 CEO's directing them to immediately implement the CDC guidelines and issue masks to 10 inmates.[SENTMARKER]The district court later denied respondents' motion to decertify the class.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2020, the district court granted the defendants' motion for a TRO and a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit denied the motion, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 1980, inmates filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated and named lead case with five other cases filed against the defendant in 1981 and 1982.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Legal Assistance to Prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiff's rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments were violated because the facility was overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking in security, and unable to provide adequately the basics of general human living needs.[SENTMARKER]Judgments were reached that required screening of all admitted inmates, individualized health care summaries for HIV-positive inmates, routine health examinations, and the use of drug therapies for HIV-positive inmates; as well as requiring that the prison not increase its inmate population, continue operating as a medium security facility, and allow plaintiffs' lawyers access to the facility.

gold_sents: In 1986, the prisoners at the Occoquan Facilites of the District of Columbia's Lorton Correctional Complex filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia government officials' overcrowding of the facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had violated the constitution, and required that the prison minimize its population.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In the wake of a prison riot, inmates at the District of Columbia's facilities in Occoquan, Virginia, brought suit in federal court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the prison violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification and a preliminary injunction imposing a population cap on the facility.[SENTMARKER]The District Court held that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]As a remedy, the District imposed an institution population cap of 1,281 and subjected each of the nineteen housing units within the facility to individual population caps.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals vacated and remanded, finding that the population cap was too broad a remedy.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] Inmates of the District of Columbia's Occoquan Facility of the Lorton Correctional Complex brought this class action under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the facility violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]In 1986, the District Court imposed a population cap on each of the nineteen housing units within the facility and ordered the District to reduce the total number of prisoners to no more than 1,281 by June 1, 1987.[SENTMARKER]The District failed to take remedial action, and the inmate population continued to swell.[SENTMARKER]In September, the District court found that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding at the Jail and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

On August 6, 2006, Prison Legal News (PLN) submitted a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]They asked the BOP to waive all search and duplication fees under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]BOP refused to grant the fee waiver and PLN appealed the decision to the Department of Justice.

The DOJ upheld the denial of the request, so on September 13, 2005, PLN filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]After several years of litigation, the parties settled in 2017.[SENTMARKER]The BOP produced the requested documents and agreed to pay $420,000 in attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2005, the non-profit legal journal Prison Legal News (PLN) filed this lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C.  552, against the BOP and the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and an order compelling the defendants to provide it with all documents responsive to its FOIA requests without any cost.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also challenged the Bureau's withholding of records and information under several FOIA disclosure exemptions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment on June 26, 2006, and ordered the Bureau to produce the remaining documents without redactions within 90 days of the court's issuance of this order.[SENTMARKER]The defendant produced approximately 11,000 pages in response to the plaintiff’s FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion in part and denied the motion for partial summary judgment in part.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2005, Prison Legal News (PLN) filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking a waiver of all search and duplication fees associated with a document request made under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The BOP denied PLN's request for a fee waiver, stating that the request did not explain why the information was of interest to the public.[SENTMARKER]On October 20, 2003, PLN appealed the denial of the fee waiver to the United States Department of Justice (DOJ).[SENTMARKER]In its appeal, PLN explained in detail how the requested information would help the public identify problems in specific BOP facilities and programs, and provided an important overall measure of program efficiency and effectiveness within BOP.[SENTMARKER]On July 27, 2007, the Court ordered BOP to process PLN’s FOIA request by July 27, 2007.[SENTMARKER]BOP produced another 1,396 pages of documents.[SENTMARKER]It also withheld 569 pages for redaction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the 102 Exhibits attached to the Plaintiff’s Fifth Motion for Summary Judgment constitute the remaining documents in contention in this litigation.

gold_sents: Four overdetained former Delaware prisoners, represented by private counsel, filed this § 1983 action against the Delaware Department of Corrections (DDOC) and Central Offender Records (COR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that inadequate staff, training, discipline, and hours of operation, along with a host of other policies, caused dysfunction and frequent over-detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought suit individually and as a class on behalf of all those incarcerated in a DDOC facility as of October 1, 2008 or later who were not or will not be released within 12 hours of the expiration of their sentence or the forwarding of a court order for release.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment because the plaintiffs' failed to demonstrate that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the overdetention problem.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2011, the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation (NHLC) filed a lawsuit in the Circuit Court of the First Circuit, State of Hawaii against the Governor of Hawaii and the Director of the Arizona Department of Corrections (D.C.) alleging that the defendants violated the rights of Native Hawaiian inmates by preventing them from practicing their religion.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to transfer the case to the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on the ground that the defendant was not, at the time of service of the summons, "doing business" in the district.[SENTMARKER]The case was then moved to the district court for the District of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the magistrate judge held a settlement conference and the parties agreed to a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required the defendants to allow outdoor worship classes six times a year for 1.5 hours each time during regularly scheduled ritual class, to allow the inmates to participate in two solstice/ox and two Makahiki celebrations each year, and to publish a communal items list in the prison chapel.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay $700.00 to the NHLC for costs incurred.

pegasus_output_sents: In the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, a group of Muslim prisoners filed this civil rights action against the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) alleging that the defendants violated their First and Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide them adequate nutrition during their 2011 and 2012 Ramadan fasts.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment, concluding that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed this interlocutory appeal, arguing that the district court defined the constitutional issue too generally, and that there was no clearly established law dictating the number of calories that a prisoner must have per day during a thirty-day period.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit granted the defendants’ motion to dismiss with prejudice, and the case was transferred to this district on April 4, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The case is now before the court.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2005, the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the Mississippi ACLU, and Holland Knight, LLP, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi against the Mississippi Department of Corrections (MDOC) on behalf of prisoners confined in Unit 32 of the Mississippi State Penitentiary (MSP), Parchman, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the MDOC violated the Eighth Amendment by subjecting prisoners to inhumane living conditions and excessive force, deprives them of medical and mental health treatment, and denies them due process in housing them in MSP.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a partial settlement of the litigation on the following terms: Stipulations and Settlement Terms (1) Defendants shall ensure that the cell to which a prisoner is moved is clean prior to the move.[SENTMARKER](2) The parties stipulated that the remedies set forth in the Consent Decree were narrowly drawn, extended no further than necessary to correct the violations of the prisoners’ federal rights, and were the least means necessary to rectify those violations.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice by stipulation of the parties.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the Mississippi ACLU, and Holland Knight, LLP, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi in June 2005 on behalf of four individual prisoners seeking relief for all prisoners confined in Unit 32 of the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Mississippi Department of Corrections subjects the prisoners to inhumane living conditions and excessive force, deprives them of medical and mental health treatment, and denies them procedural due process in housing them in unit 32.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in June 2007 and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree on June 1, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a number of remedies, including monitoring of patients on psychotropic medications in accordance with the community standard of care, developing treatment protocols to address the needs of Unit 32 patients suffering acute psychiatric crises, and developing appropriate treatment protocols.

gold_sents: This case is about the refusal of North Carolina's Department of Public Safety (DPS) to recognize Humanism as a faith group within the North Carolina state prison system.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2015, an inmate in a North Carolina prison and the American Humanist Association filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of North Carolina against officers of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety that are involved in policy decisions related to recognition of faith groups in state prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]They alleged violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and on March 29, 2018, Judge Terrence W. pegasus_output_sents: On February 25, 2015, the American Humanist Association (AHA) and an inmate of the Lanesboro Correctional Institution (LCI) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the Secretary of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety (DPS), the Commissioner of the Division of Adult Correction and Juvenile Justice, the Director of Prisons, the Superintendent of LCI, and two other DPS officials.[SENTMARKER]The AHA and the inmate alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by refusing to allow the inmate to form a Humanist study group to meet on the same terms that Defendants authorize inmates of theistic religious traditions to meet.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the AHA's motion for summary judgment, granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and permanent injunctive relief, and denied the defendants' cross-complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )

pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg for his role in a Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors out of millions of dollars.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the New York Attorney General's office and the Securities and Exchange Commission.[SENTMARKER]Bloomberg was charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 17b-5 thereunder.[SENTMARKER]According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New York, Bloomberg used his position as mayor to solicit investors to invest money in his real estate development projects.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that Bloomberg used the money to pay his personal expenses and to fund his lavish lifestyle.[SENTMARKER]The SEC also alleged that Bloomberg failed to disclose that the money was used to pay for his personal use.

Bloomberg Jr., were involved in the Ponzi scheme for more than a decade.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the scheme was run out of a New York apartment building and that the money was used to fund a lavish lifestyle that included lavish parties, expensive vacations, and expensive cars.[SENTMARKER]Bloomberg allegedly used the money to fund his lavish lifestyle, which included a Mercedes Benz, a Ferrari, and a Mercedes-Benz.

gold_sents: In 2009, patrons of an Atlanta gay bar sued the Atlanta Police Department, alleging that a raid on the bar had taken place without particularized reasonable suspicion or probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement requiring the police department to reform its policies.[SENTMARKER]However, after the judgment, the plaintiffs filed for sanctions twice because the police department had not implemented the policies.[SENTMARKER]In response to a joint motion by the parties, the Court ordered the appointment of a special master on June 22, 2016 to monitor the Atlanta Police Department's compliance with court orders and assist the parties in addressing any obstacles with compliance or relevant discovery.[SENTMARKER]After some time, the special master noted several disputes between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the police department to show cause why it should not be held in contempt for violating the court order.[SENTMARKER]However, as of September 2018, the parties were close to reaching a settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 10, 2009, a group of customers and employees of the Atlanta Eagle nightclub and Rawhide Leather filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the City of Atlanta and the Atlanta Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' civil rights by conducting a warrantless raid of the nightclub.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were detained without particularized reasonable articulable suspicion, unlawfully arrested them without probable cause, unlawfully frisked them for weapons, and unlawfully searched them without a warrant or probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in December 2010 to remediate the unlawful practices of the city's police force.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the city to implement a number of reforms, including the appointment of a special officer to monitor compliance with the terms of the consent order, the creation of a civil rights task force, and the release of the names of those who were detained during the raid.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This case arose from the unlawful raid of a gay bar by the Atlanta Police Department in September, 2009 (the "Eagle Raid").[SENTMARKER]On December 8, 2010, the parties concluded a settlement of the above-styled action under which the City agreed to undertake certain reforms intended to deter future occurrences of police misconduct such as those that took place during the Eagle Raid.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the City to show cause as to (1) why it should not be held in contempt of the Court's previous orders, see [347] and (2) why the City believes it is entitled to relief from the Court’s prior orders.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2016, the parties made a joint motion [308] to appoint a special master to receive briefing and hold a hearing on the first contempt issue and to receive 2 The City also raised disqualification charge under 28 U.S.C.CIFF (b)(1) pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 53, which this Court granted [309] on June 22.[SENTMARKER]This resulted in a consent order [323] setting forth the role and function of the special master, which was modified by another consent order (collectively, the "Special Master Order"), which was granted on June 22, 2016.

gold_sents: In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.[SENTMARKER]In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]There was no further legal action taken by either party.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1974, the Alliance to End Repression and the American Civil Liberties Union filed a class action complaint against the City of Chicago, the Chicago Police Department, the U.S. Attorney General, and the Director of the FBI, alleging that the defendants were engaging in unconstitutional conduct directed at their First Amendment activities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Chicago field office conducted "domestic security" investigations with the intent to harass and intimidate various groups and individuals for expressing their political views.[SENTMARKER]After several years, the case was settled in August of 1981 by the entry of a consent decree which was approved by a district judge.[SENTMARKER]The parties signed a settlement agreement in the fall of 1980.[SENTMARKER]The agreement runs to 31 pages, gives standing to the plaintiffs to enforce the decree by application to the district court, and empowers the plaintiffs' representatives to monitor compliance with the decree for five years.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2009, the ACLU of Chicago filed two class-action lawsuits against the City of Chicago, alleging that the City had engaged in a pattern and practice of unlawful surveillance and intelligence-gathering on individuals and organizations engaged in lawful activities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree to govern the City's investigation of political and other activities engaged in by plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree prohibited the gathering of First Amendment information unless it was so necessary to and inseparable from an investigation that its gathering cannot be avoided.[SENTMARKER]The City appealed, claiming that the consent decree did not change First Amendment law.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 19, 2015 three Chicago residents filed suit against the City of Chicago and several members of the Chicago Police Department for unlawful arrest and detention and excessive use of force at the Homan Square detention facility.[SENTMARKER]In May 2015 defendants filed a motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 2016, the Court granted the defendants motion to dismiss; the dismissal order came 150 days later, though a written opinion and order came down on January 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the Court's decision to grant the motion to dismiss to the Seventh Circuit after the written order was issued.[SENTMARKER]A Seventh Circuit panel agreed with the district court on September 30, 2019; they wrote that the appeal was not filed in a timely manner, and that the underlying case was filed after the statute of limitations had passed.[SENTMARKER]This decision was not appealed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This class-action lawsuit was filed on June 28, 2020 in response to Portland Police Bureau's allegedly illegal tactics in quelling the protests in that city after the police killing of George Floyd in May of 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were members of media and legal observers of the protests, argued that their First Amendment and Fourth Amendment rights were violated by the PPB's use of pepper spray and rubber bullets, among other weapons.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a TRO against the city, prohibiting the police from arresting or seizing the equipment of reporters or legal observers of the protests.[SENTMARKER]The court later granted a preliminary injunction against the city.[SENTMARKER]By July 16, President Trump had sent in federal officers from the DHS and USMS as reinforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs added those two organizations as defendants and filed a motion for a TRO and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The motion for temporary restraining order and the motion for preliminary injunction were both granted.[SENTMARKER]These decisions were appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which has yet to rule on them.[SENTMARKER]However, on October 9, the Ninth Circut declined to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The federal defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which remains pending.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of December 31, 2020.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2020, Disability Rights New York (DRNY) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County, alleging that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Minnesota Human Rights Act (HRA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter during televised COVID-19 pandemic briefings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in part that the ADA and RA did not require the county to provide the interpreter at every meeting because based on the interpretation services that were provided the county "effectively communicated" the relevant information to the plaintiffs at the large-group meetings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island entered a consent decree in a case brought by the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) against the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE) and the City of Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) alleging that the state violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to serve individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) in the most integrated day activity service setting appropriate for their needs, and by placing transition-age youth at serious risk of segregation.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the DOJ in September 2014 and the parties agreed to implement the consent decree on January 1, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the state to provide services and supports to individuals with I/DD in a sheltered workshop setting, provide services to those with disabilities in a non-public special education school, and provide services in the same buildings as sheltered workshops.[SENTMARKER]According to the court judgment, the state is not in full compliance with the terms and conditions of the consent consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is continuing to monitor the state's implementation of the agreement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 9, 2014, the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island entered a Consent Decree in the case of the United States Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division, alleging that Rhode Island's sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by unnecessarily segregating individuals unnecessarily.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree required the State to transform its service system to provide individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) the training and support they need to become employed in competitive, integrated jobs and fully participate in community activities of their own choosing with friends, families, and other members of society.[SENTMARKER]The State also agreed to implement an effective plan to transition individuals unnecessarily segregated in sheltered workshops to integrated employment and day settings in the community.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 19, 2016, a group of African-American residents of Florida's Jefferson County filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Jefferson County Board of Commissioners and the Florida School Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to equal representation under the "one person, one vote" principle of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]According to the 2010 Census data, the total population of Jefferson County including the prison was 14,761.[SENTMARKER]When the prison is excluded from the population count, the Black voting age population decreases to 32.73%, and the Hispanic voting age populations decreases to 2.80%.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the scheme "resulted in significant population disparities," and the state could not fall back on its reliance on census figures to justify these disparities because "[t]he... use of [a] census enumeration to support a conclusion that all of the Navy personnel on a ship actually resided within the state senatorial district in which the ship was docked upon the census figures"

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Asian Jade Society of New York and New Jersey, a fraternal organization of Port Authority Police officers of Asian or Pacific Islander descent, sued the Port Authority under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  2000e et seq., alleging that Asian American officers were passed over for promotions because of their race.[SENTMARKER]After a nine-day trial, a unanimous jury found the port authority liable for discrimination against seven of the plaintiffs under all three theories and awarded back pay and compensatory damages to each of those seven plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted equitable relief to certain of the prevailing plaintiffs in the form of retroactive promotions, seniority benefits, and salary and pension adjustments corresponding with the hypothetical promotion dates that the jury apparently selected as a basis for calculating these plaintiffs’ back pay awards.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the district court remanded the case for a new trial solely on damages and for the reconsideration of equitable relief.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2018 two US Airmen under pseudonym and OutServe-SLDN, a network of LGBTQ military service-people, filed suit against the U.S. Department of Defense, James Mattis, and Heather Wilson in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that the U.S had violated equal protection under the fifth amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented by Winston and Strawn LLP, LAMBDA Legal Defense and Education Fund, and Outserve-SLDN (now known as the Modern Military Association of America) sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing HIV positive service members to continue to serve and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that they were discharged from their duties in the Air Force due to their HIV status.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Leonie M. gold_sents: On July 10, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed this FOIA suit against U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought records pursuant to a FOIA request about the defendant's use of a contractor to process and transport immigration detainees, some of whom had allegedly suffered injury and death due to the contractor's malfeasance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an order from the court that the defendant provide the records.[SENTMARKER]This case was combined with a suit from a private plaintiff alleging mistreatment in ICE and G4S custody in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]Document production appears to be continuing smoothly at a rate of 750 pages per month, but shifting production online due to COVID-19 has yielded some issues in getting documents over to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Document production is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking information about the treatment of immigration detainees in the San Francisco area.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2018, the ACLU-NC and a local newspaper filed a FOIA request to ICE seeking records about the detention and transport of immigration detainee in the state of California.[SENTMARKER]On September 19, 2019, the parties filed a joint statement in which the parties agreed that ICE would comply with the FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]On February 6, 2020, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered ICE to produce the requested records within 30 working days.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On February 6, 2020, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking access to records related to the detention and transport of immigration detainees in the San Francisco Bay area.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU alleged that the government's efforts to detain individuals, to 17 transport them to detention centers throughout the country, and to increase the use of private transportation services created an urgent need to obtain information and records about existing relationships with private contractors and the policies and procedures they are subject to.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for summary judgment and ordered ICE to process and release all responsive records to the FOIA requests, including, but not limited to, the contracts with G4S and other private contractors for the transport of detainees, the policies, procedures, and guidelines for detaining and transporting immigration detainees, and the retention of private transport providers.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.

On July 10, 2020, the Regents of the University of California and the California Community Colleges filed a similar suit, also in the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated that the two cases were related.[SENTMARKER]Judge Tigar assigned the case to him, and the parties agreed that the case would be reassigned to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005;
